ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Anthony Vineyards management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Anthony Vineyards' safety and environmental policies are administered by the Operations Manager, who conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the PSM/CalARP/RMP Program.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Anthony Vineyards facility is located at 5512 Valpredo Ave, Bakersfield, California. The facility is approximately 2.4 miles east of Highway 99. The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural respect to the surrounding area with a mixture of farmland and residential areas.

 

The facility utilizes a refrigeration system to provide refrigeration for cold storage of grapes. In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 44,821 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance. The system, consisting of vessels, piping, valves, and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the cold storage of grapes, and fruits. Typical operating conditions range from approximately 30 psig on the low-pressure side of the system to 150 psig on the high side. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Anthony Vineyards ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For example, the facility operates in accordance with Cal-OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation. The facility co

nducts preventative maintenance and any necessary minor repairs in house, but an outside contractor is hired for major repairs or maintenance. The facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the California Mechanical Code applicable at the time of construction, which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. These safety features include ammonia sensors in the engine room. In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room and just outside of the engine room (condensers). All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that vent to the diffusion tank.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The CalARP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"An unanticipated emission of a regulated substance or other extremely hazardous substance into the ambient air from a stationary source."



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (19CCR2750.9(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (19CCR2750.9(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted during the PHA meeting on June 2, 2017, there have been no releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material to date. 

Anthony Vineyards has had one minor accident within the past 5 years. The accident was less than 100 pounds released, where the National Response Center (NRC) was not required to be notified. The date of the incident occurred on April 8, 2017 where one of the refrigeration contractors (welder) ran into the oil cooler and released ammonia. The ammonia system was shut down and offline at time of incident where approximately 30 poun

ds of ammonia was released from the system. Oil was released as well, but was mixed with ammonia. 



The CUPA (Kern County Environmental Health) has copy of the incident investigation report finding on file, and visited the facility April 8, 2017 after the facility notified the CUPA. Recommendations were made, closed out, and documented within 7 days after the incident investigation report was initiated.



The team used past experience and knowledge of other accidents at other facilities as examples of potential accidents that could occur at this facility.  In addition, accidents that have occurred at similar facilities were discussed during the HAZOP in order to draw a greater understanding of the risks involved with the use of ammonia and to recommend proven mitigation measures where appropriate. These events are identified in the Log Tables under the Recommendations / Comments column as INDUSTRY HISTORY.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Anthony Vineyards facility has an emergency response plan in effect. The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP/CalARP document. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1.) To save lives.

2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.

3.) To protect the environment.

4.) To minimize property damage.



The operator of the facility maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP and CalARP regulations.



In case of an ammonia emergency, the facility plans to evacuate all employees and contractors and activate the facility

's response plan to respond to the situation. If necessary, they will alert the local emergency responders (fire department) for assistance. The facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazards Analysis, conducted on June 2, 2017, including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Anthony Vineyards facility. The Anthony Vineyards safety committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.

 

In 2018, with the assistance of a refrigeration contractor, Anthony Vineyards completed modifications to the existing ammonia refrigeration system.  These modifications included the addition of four Pre-Cooling Rooms, one Compressor, and one Evaporative Condenser.  The ammonia charge was also increased to 29,821 pounds.  As part of this project, a Process Hazard Analysis of the new equipment was completed on May 22, 2018.  In addition, a Seismic Assessment of the new equipment was completed.



In late 2018/early 2019, Anthony Vineyards further modified the existing ammonia refrigeration system with the addition of four (4) Storage Room Accumulators with Evaporator Coils, as well as two (2) Evaporators.  With the addition of the new equipment, the ammonia charge was also increased to 44,821 pounds.  As part of the Management of Change procedure, a Process Hazard Analysis of the new equipment was completed on December 9, 2019.
